title: danny dyer right royal family flaw
story: A documentary that was as funny as it was surprising, and all the more so because the BBC did the right thing and played it absolutely straight.Genuine blue plaque television, in fact, that should never have been revisited or reformatted, not least because it would remind the Beeb that Danny’s wonderful everyman story had killed the whole WDYTYA franchise.So I’d been expecting this sucker punch, ever since its final credits rolled in .Danny Dyer’s Right Royal Family, on BBC. “A potty old adventure,” as his nibs described it, tracing Danny’s family line even further back, to Scandinavia’s King Rollo, his -times great grandfather, who I’d always assumed was a s children’s cartoon character, rather than a ninth-century Viking warrior.There were two episodes of it this time as well, which I know some of you thought were as funny as the original. Personally, I didn’t.What I hope we’re all agreed on, though, is the fact that Danny’s too busy playing Danny Dyer, the professional geezer, to be a good listener or natural TV historian.It’s an act that worked, of course, when he was wondering, “Eleanor of Aquitaine, was she a looker ” but didn’t serve him so well when presented with a longbow.“Long, innit ”The Beeb clocked this before production started, obviously, so had paired him up with dozens of head-patting historians and actors who got him to dress up as every kind of medieval t**t you can imagine. Like Mr Benn on crack, it was.Armour, codpieces, nappies, tights, doublet and hose, and a gigantic white smock, bleached with human urine, which had one grovelling “courtier” wondering: “Has all the p*** been washed out, my Lord King ”A good question.We didn’t actually get the answer, though, until part two, on Wednesday, when, after a brief detour round his ancestors, Louis IX of France, William the Conqueror and Henry II, viewers got to the nub of things, with Professor Chris Given-Wilson explaining the agonising death of Edward II: “By thrusting a hollow instrument, like the end of a trumpet, up his fundament.”“’Old on a minute,” said a rattled Danny. “He’s been stabbed  With a trumpet ”“Into his fundament.” Long pause.“Don’t tell me it’s up his a**e ”Right up it, Danny, with a red-hot poker. News which didn’t just do his “nut in”, it seemed to derail the entire documentary.They ran out of direct royal ancestors shortly afterwards as well, and the BBC adopted its stupid default setting in such circumstances. It turned Danny’s Right Royal Family into a dance and cookery show, complete with demonstrations of both, from medieval experts.It was about this time I also sussed out what was going on in the background, with all those winsome historians. An audition.The BBC was using it to find its new face of history, though why any of the blokes turned up is a mystery. Auntie’s already made it clear: “The days of white, middle-aged men explaining stuff are over.”Danny, on the other hand, can be tolerated, because he’s their new performing Cockney. A novelty act who can be dressed up and patronised so much he ended this one doing some weird medieval can-can, with his family, in front of his lost ancestral pile.A trumpet wasn’t quite shoved up his fundament as they danced, but the p*** had very much been washed out of him, my Lord King.GREAT TV lies and delusions of the month. “I think it’s going to be a really great show.” Cheryl Tweedy, The Greatest Dancer.“We do TV shows and we’re national treasures.” Jedward, Celebrity Coach Trip.“People will remember my name and I love that.” Some t**t off Ship- wrecked.IF you’re to take anything from the news experts have claimed Monday, January  was the most depressing day of the year, it’s probably the fact the experts clearly never sat through what happened eight days later, on Tuesday, January .Britain’s Top  Dogs Live: . All two-and-a-half yapping hours of it, on ITV, with a bad hangover, in the company of presenters Ben Fogle and Sara Cox.A test beyond personal endurance not because of the alcohol or dogs, who are a largely blameless lot, but the presence of their barmy owners, who attribute all sorts of superpowers to their dumb little mutts and blur the human animal relationship way beyond the point of reason and sometimes even good taste.Hits Radio DJ Gemma Atkinson, for instance, claimed: “I wouldn’t be where I am today without Norman”, her pet sproodle.Which is a hell of a guilt trip to pin on any dog.While Spandau Ballet’s Martin Kemp was seen, sitting alongside Popsie the poodle and his Wham! backing-singer we Shirlie, exclaiming: “I’ll say this for her,she does do a poo she goes into the spare bathroom.”The least you’d expect, frankly, after  years of marriage.The case study that really finished me off, though, was a dog dancing instructor called Joan Clark and her powder puff hounds, whose act, as described by Sara Cox, was: “All building up to the big finish. Can she pull it off  Joan points to the spot and it’s one, two, three pups between her legs.”CHANNEL ’s Pure is a comedy drama about a woman who suffers from the sixth sense of seeing naked people and is so tormented by her condition she screams: “F***ing stop. Make it stop.”So she can read minds as well.QUIZ show doughballs of the week. The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Real Madrid play their home football matches in which Spanish city ”John: “Barcelona.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which month of the year was named after the Roman Emperor Augustus ”Jorge: “July.”Ben Shephard: “Hajduk Split are a football team from which eastern European country ”Jenner: “Japan.”And Joe Lycett: “In his song Le On Mars, David Bowie wonderedthere was le on which planet ”Amber: “Jupiter.” Andy Murray texting Good Morning Britain with the :am request: “Please stop discussing my genitals on national television.”Andrew Neil ripping all of Ken Livingstone’s socialist fantasies about Venezuela into tiny shreds, on This Week.And The Time It Takes answer contestant John gave to the question: “The metaphorical breaking of which body part brings good luck to an actor ” “Neck.” A thought that’s occurred to me every time I watch the Baftas.FAIR play, I thought, to Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair. They really seemed to have all the important ITV advertising bases covered.First thing in the morning they’re dropping regular hints about “bothersome vaginas” during Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain sht. Then there they were again, on Sunday night, directly before Gemma Collins skated at Dancing On Ice.Although, I say “skated,” you’d see marginally more movement from the Larsen C ice shelf in Antarctica than we got from Gemma on this week’s show.The heroic Matt Evers had to shove, heave, prod and generally wield her like a hypermarket shopping trolley, in fact, just to get Gemma turning on her axis.One very calculated burst of tears later, though, the mug punters had voted her through for yet another week and she’d parked her over-entitled backside on Piers Morgan’s sofa early yesterday morning.So where the hell was Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair when the occasion really called for them Asleep on the job, that’s where. Call yourself a “relief” GREAT Sporting Insights. Martin Keown: “Abramovich has spent £.billion at Cha. That’s £million per championship.”Jermaine Jenas: “The ball misses Trippier’s head by a second.”John Inverdale: “Warren Gatland began his reign  years ago to the day, tomorrow.”And Paul Merson: “Petr Cech was a great shop spotter.”Sent in by Tom Baxter, Denny, Stirlingshire. Picture research Jimbo.RANDOM TV irritations: The widespread but mistaken belief that “you just can’t have too much Romesh Ranganathan”.The Voice UK audience member who shouted: “Olly, I think you should sing.” Jonathan Davies’ complete inability to keep his Welsh bias out of the rugby commentary box.ITV’s Small Fortune already looking like the worst game show of the year.  And catchphrase-chasing hosts Alesha Dixon and Jordan Banjo declaring, “Things are getting really seri-arse”, on The Greatest Dancer, just at the point things were getting even more tedi-arse.TV OBSERVATION round. Who said the following last week “It looks like it’s dragging its legs on the floor, doing a hip wiggle. But it’s actually scent-marking with its anal glands, on the side of a track, on the side of a road, anywhere a passing male might snf it.”A Iolo Williams on Winterwatch’s pine marten B Sam Matterface on Dancing On Ice’s Gemma Collins Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa tells northern ireland wont
story: NewsTheresa May tells Northern Ireland she wont break her promise of no hard borderThe Prime Minister is on her way to calm nerves as she attempts to revive Brexit plans and win over Northern Irish business leadersShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  FEB NewsMay was expected to announce her Government would find a way to deliver Brexit that honours commitments to Northern Ireland "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May will today pledge to business leaders in Northern Ireland that there will be no “hard border” with the Republic.The Prime Minister is travelling to the province to calm nerves as she attempts to resurrect her Brexit deal.No insiders believe she needs to reassure businesses that she will not go back on her vow to avoid a hard border with physical customs checks. Mrs May was expected to say she would do her “utmost” to support peace, prosperity and progress there. She will tell them: “We will find a way to deliver Brexit that honours our commitments to Northern Ireland... that commands broad support across the community.” However, a former Northern Ireland first minister undermined her bid to tackle shyanxieties.  Lord Trimble, an architect of the Good Friday peace deal, is seeking a judicial review of the controversial “backstop” designed to keep the Irish border open. Brexiteers fear it could tie the UK into a permanent customs union. Lord Trimble, says it should be removed from any deal. Mrs May will tomorrow hold talks in Belfast with the Democratic Unionist Party, which props up her minority Tory Government.  DUP leader Arlene Foster has put the PM under pressure over the “toxic” backstop she said “drives a coach and horses” through the Good Friday deal and could potentially “separate” Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK following Brexit. Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald and deputy Michelle O’Neill, who support the backstop, also meet Mrs May. Meanwhile, the PM invited Tory rebels to No to get their support. Mrs May went on hold a conference call with  EU chiefs of major firms she hopes can pressure their governments to back a new UK plan. The EU insists the backstop stays.

title: ex loan company salesman lifts
story: NewsEx loan company salesman lts lid on exploitative tactics used to target poorEXCLUSIVE: Former Provident agent Brian Higham, , has turned back to whistleblow on the company, and a role in which he says he felt must "entrap people who were already in poverty"ShareCommentsByTom Parry:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsBrian Higham is speaking out against the tactics of his former workplace Provident "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA whistleblower who resigned from doorstep lender Provident over alleged exploitative tactics claims its hard-up customers are deliberately locked into a cycle of debt. Brian Higham felt pressure to persuade people with little cash to take out new loans or to refinance ones they had nearly paid off. As a Provident agent, he says he was told to befriend clients so he could convince them to borrow more. Brian, , left the Bradford-based firm in  after more than two years. In an exclusive interview with the Mirror, he said: “We never wanted the cycle of debt to end. “I felt like I had to entrap people who were already in poverty. “People who are on benefits don’t have much money, so they can always be persuaded. We were giving them the hard sell to get them into more debt. “We would approach around key dates when people need more money, like before Christmas and at the start of the new school year.”   Brian’s allegations come weeks after the Commons’ Business Select Committee demanded that the financial regulator take action against Provident after it “cynically” advertised .% APR loans to families over Christmas. Among the photos on Provident’s festive mailshot was one of a smiling young girl with a caption saying it would not be Christmas without “the look on her face”. Committee chair, Labour MP Rachel Reeves, wrote to the Financial Conduct Authority. She said she thought that “Provident cynically used the intense pressure on household finances over Christmas to target vulnerable customers”. “Provident tried to tug on the people’s heartstrings with [an] emotionally loaded message.” Provident remains the market leader in many parts of the UK because of its face-to-face relationships with customers. But Brian alleges this is used to encourage clients to keep taking out loans. He said: “Customer experience managers befriend these people, so the customer feels they are like part of the family. You get invited to barbecues and weddings. A bond of trust is created, but that is the deception. “There was a sense of a countdown towards a loan being paid off. We didn’t want customers to get to that point. The idea was they would be persuaded to stay in habitual debt. I came across people who had six or more loans. Others had been in debt for  or  years.”   Last week, it emerged that Provident – formed in  – shed a fth of its value on the London Stock Exchange. The lender still expects annual profits for  to be above poundmillion, but warned profits will be down due to an increase in bad debt in its Vanquis credit card ision. Provident’s car loan business, Moneybarn, is under an FCA investigation over affordability assessments and the treatment of clients in financial distress. In , BBC’s Panorama show interviewed relatives of a vulnerable shyschizophrenic woman who they said was given thousands of pounds in Provident loans. MPs have also scrutinised the firm. Last year, it had to give back poundmillion to customers for misselling financial products. Richard Frost, , had several loans with Provident after an agent called to his home in Birmingham two years ago. The father-of-two said: “Whenever I got close to paying it off, they were always around to offer me more money. “I felt like they wanted to extend them out for as long as possible.” Brian approached the Mirror after we launched the Fair Credit For All campaign with actor Michael Sheen last month. Brian says he resigned over practices which “manipulate the most vulnerable in our society”. Provident insists it lends “responsibly”, and said it will fully investigate the Mirror’s findings. Last night, a spokeswoman said agents are recorded when they visit customers to ensure they have been treated fairly. She explained that there is no commission to employees who set up loans or collect payments on those loans. Affordability checks have been tightened following the Financial Conduct Authority’s high-cost credit review published last year, she added. “Our customers need access to credit to live their lives. “We lend responsibly, our customers know what they need to pay back as the amount they repay is fixed at the outset and we work with them should their circumstances change and they find themselves in financial dficulties. “We’re committed to doing the right thing by our customers. Provident does not recognise the behaviours mentioned and will investigate these allegations thoroughly.”

title: gang filmed mowing down defenceless
story: NewsGang filmed mowing down defenceless teenager before they stabbed him to deathWARNING - DISTRESSING FOOTAGE Lord Promise Nkenda, , was rammed by the BMW before being chased down and brutally stabbed in Newham, east LondonShareByEmily Pennink:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video shocking-cctv-shows-moment-group-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the moment a gang used a stolen car to mow down a defenceless teenager before he was kned to death in a horric Valentines Day attack. Lord Promise Nkenda was walking along the pavement in Newham, east London, when the BMW containing five youths accelerated towards him. He was hit by the car then pursued by four of the boys on foot into an alleyway where he was repeatedly stabbed in the head, back and chest in seconds. Paramedics battled to save his le but Promise was pronounced dead at the scene at about .pm on Wednesday February  last year. Prosecutor Alan Kent QC had said that Promise was deliberately run down by a car containing -year-olds Shemar Dawes, Ephraim Idris, Anton Muir, Ishaq Abdille and a -year-old boy who cannot be named for legal reasons.   The defendants from east London, who were aged  and  at the time of the attack, had denied murder but were found guilty following an Old Bailey trial. Abdille and Dawes were detained for le with a minimum term of  years. Idris, who was cleared of the murder of another -year-old six months before, was handed a minimum term of  years. Muir was sentenced to at least  years and the -year-old was given a minimum of  years.   Detective Chief Inspector Dave Whellams, from Scotland Yard, said: This group acted together from start to finish to execute this murder. They were ruthless in their determination to kill Promise and have refused to co-operate with police from the outset. Promise had his whole le ahead of him and wanted to pursue a career in the music industry. He stood no chance against the onslaught this group inflicted on him. The ages and determination of those involved - a boy who was  at the time of the attack and a group of other teenagers - is chilling.   The victims brother Patrick said: Promise was the youngest of our family and everyone always sought to protect him, however, on the night that he died, we could not be there to protect him. Promise died in a sustained and frenzied kne attack, he died alone and cold in the middle of the street. We never have got to say goodbye to him, we never got to tell him how much we loved and cared for him.   We feel empty and numb, but most of all incredibly sad. A part of us all died with him, alone on that east London street. These boys need to learn that killing one another is not the way, this should not be part of everyday le, seeing a young person stabbed on the news should be the exception, not the norm. An example should be made of anyone that carries a kne and anyone who hangs around with those that do to make it clear this is not the way to live, this is not what being a man is about.

title: grieving parents say social media
story: Â£ minimum use, irrespective of any previous use. Â£ for internet use, irrespective of any previous use. "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn autistic man’s addiction to social media led to his suicide, his parents believe.Anne and Mark Braithwaite said their -year-old lad Jake was independent and healthy before buying an iPad and creating accounts on sites such as Facebook to try to make friends. Their son, who quickly became withdrawn, exhausted and depressed, killed himself six months later.Mrs Braithwaite said Jake became so involved with the virtual world it was to the “point of obsession”. She added: “No matter how we tried to restrict the hours of his access to this online social world, he would find a way around it, getting little or no sleep, and becoming emotionally overwhelmed.“He began having constant headaches ... and fits of shaking.  “His rapid decline from an independent, healthy, successful young man to the gaunt, depressed suicidal lad he became we attribute to his engagement with the digital world and social media.” Speaking after an inquest into the welding apprentice’s death, Mrs Braithwaite added that when Jake was younger, she and her husband restricted his access to the internet, digital games and social media. They felt he was too vulnerable for some of the hurtful comments online. She added: “Interpreting what’s real, and not real, is dficult for most people - autistic people see things in black and white,” she said, adding that imposing such restrictions became much more dficult when Jake became an adult. The coroner in Jakes home city of York concluded he had taken his own le.  The couple, who run the Braithwaite Gallery in Low Petergate, York said he became unable to disconnect from the virtual world. Facebook said it cared deeply about the wellbeing of people who used Facebook and its thoughts went out to those who had been affected by these kinds of issues. It added: “We recognise that mental health is a complex and nuanced issue, which is why we work with experts – including The Samaritans – to guide us on our approach. “We’re working with independent companies, policy makers, and experts to get a better understanding of the relationship between technology and well-being, which reinforces the need for more research. “We also devote signicant resources into developing technology which has helped first responders reach around , people globally who have needed help.” Mental health chiefs have taken action to ensure patients with autism receive better care since his death the inquest heard. Managers from Tees, Esk and Wear Valleys NHS Foundation Trust conceded there were shortcomings in the care and support given to Jake in the months before his death last May.  They said too many dferent members of staff were involved in Jake’s care and communications between dferent departments and sections were not good enough. They revealed that after a ‘serious incident review’ an action plan was drawn up to improve staff training across the trust to ensure a better understanding of the condition. The inquest conclusion was suicide.

story: NewsHatton Garden ringleader Basil pulled off a £m raid five years beforeMichael Seed, , is accused of being the youngest member of the gang that swiped £.m of gold, cash and gemsShareCommentsByTom Pettor:,  FEB NewsThe Hatton Garden raid stunned the nation when it took place in  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Hatton Garden heist ringleader known as Basil had pulled off a “strikingly similar” jewellery raid five years shyearlier, a court heard. title: history buffs debunk popular myths
story: NewsHistory buffs debunk some popular myths - from Cleopatras status to Napoleons heightIf you think that witches were burned at Salem and Sir Isaac Newton had an apple fall on his head, read onShareCommentsByJulie McCaffrey:,  FEB NewsTurns out Cleopatra wasnt Egyptian after all "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThought Cleopatra was Egyptian, witches were burned at the stake after the Salem Witch Trials and Napoleon was a bit of a short arse  Well, think again, as these are just a few ‘facts’ we were taught in history which just aren’t true. Magazine History Revealed has debunked a top  of fake facts you thought you knew, but it turns out you never did: AMERICA DIDN’T BECOME INDEPENDENT ON JULY  On July , fireworks and festivities across the US celebrate America’s independence from Britain, gained in . What is interesting is that the War of Independence carried on after July ,  and would do so until the Treaty of Paris was signed seven years later. The day was chosen to commemorate when the Declaration of Independence was finalised, rather than the end of the war. The colonies considered themselves independent but it wouldn’t be until September ,  that Britain formally recognised this. John Adams and Thomas Jefferson, the only two people who signed the Declaration of Independence and also became Presidents of the US, both died on July ,  – the th anniversary of the Declaration. NO WITCHES WERE BURNED AT SALEM Witches being burned at the stake is an image that crops up whenever the infamous witch trials of Salem, Massachusetts, are mentioned. In , more than  people were suspected of witchcraft and  were found guilty after rumours filled the local people with fear.   But despite the many paintings and images of witches being burned at the stake, no-one at the Salem trials was executed this way. The guilty were hanged, while one man, farmer Giles Corey, who refused to plead was pressed between stones for two days before he died. Many people think that all the “witches” were women, but a quarter of them were men. AN APPLE DIDN’T FALL ON NEWTON’S HEAD Like Archimedes’ Eureka moment in the bath, Sir Isaac Newton’s altercation with an apple, leading to his theory of gravity is well-known. Newton apparently did witness an apple falling from a tree near his home in  but his theory of gravity was already partly formed in his mind. It’s also unlikely it fell on his head. He seems to have used the tale as an easy way to illustrate his findings. Newton was the second Lucasian Professor of Mathematics at the University of Cambridge - a position which just over  years later was held by Professor Stephen Hawking. CLEOPATRA WASN’T EGYPTIAN She remains the most famous woman of the Ancient world, yet it might come as a surprise to many that Cleopatra wasn’t Egyptian. The famed lover of both Julius Caesar and Mark Antony was descended from the Macedonian Greek Ptolemaic dynasty, which took over Egypt after the death of Alexander the Great in BC. She was the first in her line to learn Egyptian and embraced many of the country’s traditions. But she was also the last of her line as after her death in BC, her kingdom became part of the Roman Empire. COLUMBUS NEVER SET FOOT IN AMERICA During his  expedition to the Americas, Christopher Columbus never actually set foot on what we now know as North America. Instead it’s believed he set foot on an island in the Bahamas, as well as Cuba and Hispaniola – now the Dominican Republic and Haiti. He also wasn’t the first European to reach the continent, as th-century Icelandic explorer Le Erikson is believed to have made landfall on the Canadian coast in c AD. He named the area Vinland due to the abundance of grapevines. NAPOLEON WASN’T SHORT During the Napoleonic Wars of – between Britain and France, the British media repeatedly ridiculed French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte for being short.   This belief even coined the Napoleon complex – the idea that some people aggressively gain power to make up for short stature. Napoleon was actually believed to be ft in – average height of a man in the early th century. However, due to a confusion about French units of measurement, he was originally said to be ft in. CAESAR WASN’T BORN BY C-SECTION Everyone knows where the word caesarean – the surgical delivery of a baby – comes from, don’t they  It’s a common belief that the name was coined as Julius Caesar was born this way in BC but there are some issues with this. In Ancient Rome, caesareans were carried only outthe mother had died during childbirth but Caesar’s mother, Aurelia Cotta, was known to have survived. The word caesar means to cut so it’s possible that one of his ancestors was born this way, creating the family name. RING O’ ROSES ISN’T ABOUT THE PLAGUE The lyrics of popular nursery rhyme, Ring a Ring o’ Roses, are often said to reference the cheery topic of the Black Death. But folklore experts have dismissed the idea, which only appeared in the th century, as many versions of the rhyme don’t include lyrics that could be about the disease. Some scholars believe it has pagan roots and all falling down is not a reference to dying of plague but an instruction to curtsy. The plague killed more than  million people across Europe during the th century. VIKING HELMETS WEREN’T HORNED A Viking is hard to to imagine without a horned helmet. But there is no evidence to suggest that the fearsome Norse warriors ever wore them. None have even been found. At a performance of Richard Wagner’s Der Ring des Nibelungenin the s, horned helmets were worn by the Viking characters creating the familiar and stereotypical image.These may have been inspired by ceremonial horned attire worn during the Nordic bronze age, which signicantly predatesthe Vikings.NERO NEVER FIDDLED Roman Emperor Nero has been painted as one of history’s villains – however there’s one story that shouldn’t be believed. In AD , a fire swept through Rome. So the tale goes, Nero played the fiddle while the city was razed. He was actually  miles away in Antium, and ordered that his palace be opened up for the homeless. The fiddle wouldn’t be invented for another thousand years. He did however have his mother Agrippina killed, so he wasn’t all good by any means.  For the full feature, see the latest issue of History Revealed magazine, out now

story: NewsLibby Squire: Neighbour claims to have heard a woman’s "blood curdling" screamThe mum-of-two, who lives round the corner, said she heard the scream  minutes after the last confirmed sighting of Libby in HullShareCommentsByLucy ThorntonMark Branagan:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video libby-squire-police-continue-searching-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA neighbour claims to have heard a woman’s “blood curdling” scream the night Libby Squire vanished. The mum-of-two says she was reading in bed when she heard the panicked cry of a woman in the street outside. The startled woman, who has reported it to police, said it was .am on Friday -  minutes after the last confirmed sighting of Libby. Libby was last seen sitting on a bench in Hull, East Yorkshire on Thursday at .pm, less than  yards away. Today her distraught parents, held hands as they released an emotional video begging her to get in touch. Mum Lisa Squire, from High Wycombe in Buckinghamshire, said: “It is breaking my heart not knowing where you are.”   The video was released as Humberside Police took to rubber dinghies for a painstaking search of nearby Barmston Drain waterway. They used an underwater camera in one of two frozen waterways, both a few minutes walk from Libby’s home. Witnesses have told how Libby was turned away from the Wellly nightclub on Thursday night for being too drunk. A pal put her in a taxi and she was dropped off outside her home a mile away. But her neighbours said she never made it through her front door and went off staggering down the street. She ended up sat on a nearby bench where she was caught on CCTV. The scream was allegedly heard just around the corner from netball player Libby’s terraced shared student house on Wellesley Avenue.   The concerned mum of two, who lives in nearby Heathcote Street near where it joins Wellesley Avenue, said: “We did hear screaming at . on Thursday night. “I was just in bed reading. We do get a lot of students who live in the road that Libby lives in who use this road as a cut through. “They go past screaming, shouting and singing. It’s not unusual. “But this made us sit up. It sounded like someone being attacked. The scream sounded like it was coming from someone who was scared. “It was someone walking quite close past our house. It was just one female scream. “It was really shrill and urgent. It made me sit up and think ‘Oh my God’.  “Then we heard other voices muttering very low, murmuring and then more screams and more male voices. “Then we heard the slamming of a door. It sounded like a wooden door or a garden gate. “It was just very odd,” added the woman, a Hull University graduate whose dad is a retired policeman. “We didn’t think about it again until the police came round knocking on everybody’s doors on Saturday,” she recalled. “We talked about it and remembered the scream and rang .”   Humberside Police have still not come around to take a statement after she reported the incident on Saturday evening. The force has been contacted for comment. Meanwhile, the hunt for the missing girl has been stepped up with officers rummaging through bins and lting drain covers in search of clues. The Hull University philosophy and religious studies student moved into her shared house with two other flat mates four months ago. Her disappearance has stunned and frightened fellow residents and students. Student Tom Wilkinson, , a pal of Libby’s flatmate Chloe Wise, said: “Everyone is scared. Everyone is still worried for her. No one feels safe when they go on a night out. “As students we got out a lot but it’s scary thinking you can’t even get a taxi back and be safe.”  Louisa Amasanti, , said: “It’s scary and surreal. No one is going anywhere alone. “Everyone has all kinds of theories but people seem to think she wandered off somewhere and fell somehow.” Her father Russell, , said in their video appeal: “Libby is our kind, thoughtful, beautul girl who is loved by so many people. As you can appreciate, this is a very dficult time for us both. “We would like to thank everyone for their help and support so far. “Your messages and kind words are a great source of strength for us both. “Please come forward with any information you may have no matter how small or irrelevant it may be, we just want Libby home.” Libby’s mother, Lisa, , added: “Libby, my darling pie. We just want to know that you are safe. “Please get in touch with us any way you can. The whole family is missing you especially me and your dad, sisters and brother. “I miss you so much. It is breaking my heart not knowing where you are. I love you more.”

title: mum threes life saved beautician
story: NewsMum-of-threes le saved by beautician who spotted cancerous mole during facialErika Hodgkiss, who noticed the melanoma on Jayne Hobbs skin, is one of a growing band of beauticians, hairdressers and therapists who have signed up for training to detect skin cancerShareCommentsByRosie Taylor:,  FEB NewsJayne Hobbs, , had ignored a mole on her chest but beautician Erika Hodgkiss realised it was melanoma "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mother-of-three whose beautician spotted she had a dangerous form of skin cancer during a pampering facial said she is lucky to be alive.Jayne Hobbs, , had ignored a mole on her chest but beautician Erika Hodgkiss realised it was melanoma - an aggressive form of skin cancer which kills six people a day in the UK. Mrs Hobbs, , said: Its hard to imagine what could have happenedI hadnt gone for a facial with Erika but I know I might not be sitting here today. Mrs Hobbs, an accountant from Chislehurst, Kent, admitted she had noticed a mole at the top of her chest was darker than normal while she was on holiday in the south of France in August, but dismissed it, thinking the colour change was caused by tanning. But when she went for a facial with Mrs Hodgkiss in October, the beautician told her she was worried it had changed since their last session and urged her to visit a doctor.  Mrs Hobbs said: Im an optimist so even when the GP referred me to a dermatologist who told me he wanted to take the mole off, I didnt think it would really be cancer. But when I went back to the clinic the consultant asked me to sit down and told me the results had come back saying it was melanoma. I was so shocked. She had to undergo further surgery to remove more skin to ensure the cancer had not spread, leaving an inch-long scar on her chest. Luckily the results came back clear, although she is now keeping a close eye on her other moles. She said: Theres quite a big scar there now - but Im alive so thats all that counts. I cant believe my own naivety that I had noticed the mole but thought it was fine. I think we have a big problem with recognising skin cancer in this country.   Skin cancer is on the rise in Britain, with melanoma rates soaring by  per cent in the past  years, and it is now the fth most-common cancer in the UK. The UK has higher mortality rates from melanoma than the European average, which experts blame on late diagnoses. Mrs Hodgkiss is one of a growing band of beauticians, hairdressers and therapists who have signed up for training to detect skin cancer in a bid to improve Britains survival rates. Cancer charity Skcin has trained nearly , beauty professionals to recognise the disease since it launched the Mascedonline training course last year. The scheme was inspired by the idea that more people have their skin looked at closely on a regular basis by a beautician or hairdresser than by their GP. Within just eight months of completing the training, Mrs Hodgkiss, , has helped saved the le of Mrs Hobbs and two other women, all of whom had surgery to remove melanoma tumours. The beautician, who specialises in facials at her salon in Crockenhill, Kent, took the course because she occasionally had clients ask questions about their skin which she couldnt answer. But she was shocked by the number of suspect skin cancer cases she started noticing. I just cant believe how many people I have seen with something unusual on their skin in just a few months, she said. Sometimes they have no idea because the mark is on their back but most of the time they are aware it is there but they say: Oh thats nothing, its just a mole. I tell them Ive been on the course and encourage them to get anything suspicious checked by a doctor. Luckily the three women who were diagnosed with melanoma have come out the other side but its scary to think it would have spreadI hadnt spotted it. If I hadnt seen them for a facial, they wouldnt have known they had cancer. Mrs Hobbs said: If I hadnt had that facial,Erika hadnt seen the mole,she hadnt been on the course, I dont know what would have happened. Im so lucky all those things came together just in time. Nearly half of people taking the Masced training course were beauticians, hairdressers or barbers, but nail technicians, chiropodists, masseurs, chiropractors and even dentists have also signed up. Claire Dale, campaign manager at Skcin, said: A year on from launching our campaign its amazing to hear about three lives saved by just one of our beauty therapists. With nearly , professionals now trained by Masced, we hope it will save hundreds of lives every year. The Masced training programme relies on donations. To help, go to: www.justgiving skcin donate.

story: NewsHow boy, , has built up £k-a-year eBay empire from familys milk parlourSchoolboy Tommy Howard officially launched Dog In A Box on eBay last year - named after his pet dog Oreo - and never takes a day offShareCommentsByOlive Loveridge-Greene:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsTommy Howard, , inside his warehouse in Hawkchurch, Devon "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old entrepreneur has built up an online toy shop from his familys milking parlour - and now turns over pound, a year. The pint-sized businessman does all the work himself - phoning manufacturers, liaising with wholesalers, and even cycling on his bike after school every day to meet the postie. Last year he tucked away an impressive pound, profit, helped by a festive surge of his best-selling product Top Trumps and paddling pools he flogged during the heatwave. Tommy, from Hawkchurch, Devon, who dreams of warehouse shops all over the country, said: People may question my age but to that I would say Why not  Im passionate and capable and thats what you need in business. Im probably more capable than some adults. I used to find people didnt take me seriously when I first started out. People shouldnt think because Im young I can be taken advantage of. I know my stuff.   The Year  student first came up with the idea of launching his own business when younger brother Jamie, now , put a pound Nerf Gun on his birthday list two years ago. Noticing how expensive and popular they were, Tommy started researching prices online and found a second-hand bundle on Gumtree for pound. With money earned from selling his chicken eggs across his village, the teen bought them, scrubbed them up, and listed each one inidually on eBay for pound-pound. He sold out within a week and, in true entrepreneurial spirit, Tommy decided to use the pound profit to buy ten more of the toy from Gumtree. He said: I was just watching a normal YouTube video where at the end they showed a tour of their warehouse, where they kept their merchandise and I was just thinking ‘wow imagine owning a company that can warrant a warehouse like that. “I was then on a mission to make my very own business. “When Jamie put it on his birthday list I was shocked at how expensive they were.  “For a -year-old pound is a lot of money. I did a bit of research online and found brand new were so expensive and you could buy big second hand Nerf bundles for the amount you could buy one new gun. “I was buzzing to make my first sale. “They had a couple of scratches on so I gave them a clean up before I took pictures and listed them online. The price was a pound or two cheaper than what they were retailing at all the big stores so I could still have the edge. He added: I bought another bundle with my profit and my pocket money and they sold out within days too. I loved the whole process of deciding which products to go for, seeing how customers react. Demand was growing and I found myself selling quite a few Nerf Guns to Portugal which I had to use a courier for. I foundI started misspelling keywords Id find a tonne of cheap Nerf Guns. I did this until I rinsed Gumtree and eBay of all their cheap guns. The schoolboy sold more than , in a year until he noticed his margins were shrinking - and looked for a solution.  I remember thinking to myselfI don’t expand I’ll never grow at this rate, he said. “The Nerf guns were popular and I would often find myself out of stock. Despite a teacher telling him it wasnt worth the hassle, he phoned Hasbro - who make Nerf guns - and the toy giant provided him with a list of suppliers. He tried to find a wholesaler but was told he needed to be a registered business in order to buy in bulk. Tommy said: “I mentioned it to my business teacher and he said there was no point contacting them as they would only sell to big companies directly. “I said to dad “Let’s just do it, what’s the worst that can happen anyway ” “So that day after school I rang up Hasbro and it had the best possible outcome I imagined. “Of course, they couldn’t supply us directly but they gave us a list of their biggest wholesale distributors who stock their products and with that we got ringing and account making.” He registered as a business on eBay in March  and ordered in  dferent kinds of products from wholesalers. He got his engineer dad Charlie, , to put up shelves in one of their converted milking parlours at their farm to store his products, and toys started flying off the shelves. He now stocks more than , products, selling an average of  a day and shipping to more than  countries. Every day, the savvy teenager gets home from school at pm with only  minutes packaging and labelling time before meeting local postman Leo at the village postbox half a mile away. Best-sellers include Glove-a-Bubbles, Nerf Guns and fun-sand and he has recently added a pound touch screen as his top-ticket item.  Tommy has managed to make thousands of pounds while his peers begin their GCSEs, making his dad and -year-old mum, Claire, a nanny, proud. He has his own sales manager at a suppliers in Cambridgeshire who he said took me under his wing. Tommy said: When we phoned up it really started to feel like I was becoming a proper business. I was helped around by a guy called Jimmy Singh who was the nicest sales manager ever. He took me under his wing and would help me find things that had good margins and were selling. Unfortunately Nerf Guns just didn’t have margins that could make me any money. “So, with that I decided I would sell toys as a whole and my sales manager helped me do just that. “He gave me a heads up on this new product Glove-A-Bubbles. They were just releasing TV campaigns going out with it which was going to boost the sales.” Tommy placed his first wholesale order with  units of Glove-A-Bubbles as well as some other arts and crafts toys. He said: “It was my first taste of what it was like to be a big seller on eBay. I had already bought a pound second-hand industrial label maker which really helped with the growing orders. “I noticed my sales go up almost instantly. In the first couple of weeks I sold eight units of Glove-A-Bubbles. “Then one day I turned my phone after school and I couldn’t believe my eyes.  “It read ‘paid post now  items’. I showed my dad and we thought it was a glitch. “But it wasn’t I had actually sold  items in a day. “I got home and instantly ordered another  units. But after a three-month high as Dog In A Boxs best-selling product, Tommy saw his orders plummet to zero when manufacturer Zing ceased advertising. The youngster, who named the business after his dog Oreo, said: My sales were going up and up and up and then all of a sudden I had nothing. I had no idea what happened. I phoned up Jimmy and he said that the company pulled the TV advertisement. He didnt know why but my sales were flat after that. “I’ve still got  units of them as I’ve only managed to sell  in the past year. “But it taught me a hard lesson about dead stock. Theres no guarantee in business. Keeping an eye on customer trends, Tommy made a splash of money selling paddling pools during last year’s summer heatwave.  He said: I thought there must have been demand for swimming pools and it complimented all my other products. To test the water I bought four, listed them in the morning and by the end of the day they were gone. I was shocked but that confirmed to me they were a winner. Id buy them for as low as pound. and sell them for around pound. I think I sold about  in total. I was really happy with that. He added: “I’ve got the best postman ever who collects from the post-box at the top of our lane and every day at :pm. “I either walk, cycle orthe weather is really nasty or the sacks are too heavy I get my dad to drive me up. With his business growing by the day Tommy is planning a trip to a Birmingham trade show next week. Tommy hopes to roll-out Dog In A Box across the UK, making it the go-to destination for shoppers. Tommy said: I dont want to be held back or restricted to toys. Im always looking to what  I can add. Im looking to get more technology products listed as everyone could be a potential customer. I want to have warehouses across the country similar to Screwfix and Travis Perkins where you have a warehouse in the back and the counter at the front. “I dont think Brexit will affect me doing that as the majority of my sales are from within the UK.

story: NewsSix-stone man who can barely walk gets benefits back after being told to find workStephen Smith, from Kensington, Liverpool, was forced to get a pass out from hospital to fight the Department of Work and PensionsShareCommentsByLiam ThorpBradley JollyJonathan Humphries:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video man-who-weighed-barely-six-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A man who was told to find work despite weighing just six stone and being barely able to walk will finally get paid all the benefits hes entitled to, it emerged today.Stephen Smith, , became so weak and unwell he was admitted to hospital over Christmas.But, despite struggling walk, he was deemed fit to work by the Department of Work and Pensions. Mr Smith got a pass out from hospital to fight the cruel decision, which had repeatedly denied him Employment Support Allowance , and has finally won his appeal, the Liverpool Echo reports.Now, Stephen will receive back-payments for the money he has wrongly been denied, including all ESA sums. A spokesman for the DWP said: We are sorry for the experience Mr Smith has had and we are committed to ensuring that people with health conditions get the support theyre entitled to.   Following the independent tribunal’s ruling, he is now receiving full ESA support. While Mr Smith continued to receive benefits and support during his appeal, we can confirm he will shortly receive all back-payments for ESA due.”Repeated calls to grant Stephen ESA were denied - despite written evidence from doctors stating that he couldnt walk for  metres without collapsing with pain and exhaustion.Stephen, of Kensington, Liverpool, has suffered with a number of serious conditions for several years. His most debilitating illness is Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease, an incurable respiratory problem that causes severe breathing issues and gets worse over time. But he also suffers with excruciating Osteoarthritis, has an enlarged prostate and uses a colostomy bag to go to the toilet.   Despite all of this, he failed a DWP work capability assesment in  - which meant his ESA payments were stopped and he was told to sign on for a pound a week Jobseekers Allowance, visit the job centre once a week and prove he was looking for work. Throughout this period, Stephen was living alone and didnt know where to turn as his health deteriorated. He said: I could only make it to the kitchen to make food once a day. I had no muscles in the back of my leg which meant I couldnt stand up at all - and had to lean or sit down all the time - but they were telling me I was fit for work. He believes he could have diedit wasnt for two men, Tony Nelson and Terry Craven. Tony runs the CASA community centre in Hope Street which offers support to people who dont know where to turn.   Tony introduced Mr Smith to Terry, a former city council welfare officer who works at the CASA advising people on benefit claims. After Stephen was kicked off ESA, Terry took up his case and battled with the DWP to get him the benefits he knew he deserved. In response to the DWPs U-turn, Terry said: It is an outrage for a senior citizen of one of the richest countries in the world to have been treated like this by a Government department. Steve should not have been deprived of his just entitlement for a week let alone two years. He has worked all his le and ran several businesses successfully. This Government’s policies and its denial of poverty are challenged by Steve’s circumstances. No justication could possibly exonerate this Govermment’s responsibility for Steve’s plight. I am just glad this is not a death story. Am I owed back payments  Most of those affected are people who moved from incapacity benefit to the contributory version of ESA. The DWP says it will contact those hit. How much am I owed  The average payment so far has been pound,. Early estimates suggested a small number lost poundk. About , entitled to the severe disability premium were estimated to be owed around pound, each. When will I be paid  poundm arrears will be paid to , people whose cases post-date  through to April . Another poundm will then be paid to an estimated , people whose cases pre-date  in the   financial year. How will I be paid  The same way you normally get benefits, usually your bank account, within  weeks of being contacted by the DWP. What about claimants who have died  If your relative died while waiting for payment, you should be entitled to claim their benefits. The DWP claims it is trying to find their families so they can have that money. Will that money be paid back with interest  Its not clear. Ms Newton dodged this question when asked directly in the House of Commons. For more information click here.  This included sending the opinions of two separate doctors who both confirmed the signicant dficulty and pain experienced by Mr Smith when completing simple movements and daily activities. One doctors note stated: It is my opinion that Mr Smith could not walk  metres without pain or exhaustion. But despite this, in January last year, his appeal was rejected by the DWP who told him that he hadnt scored the required number of points to deem him as having limited capability for work. But Stephen and Terry continued to battle over the next year and eventually were granted the chance to fight the decision in a tribunal earlier this month -  months on from that DWP rejection. Speaking today, Terry said: I have got lots of cases like Steves - I have a client at the moment who is actually on dialysis and has been thrown off benefits.

story: NewsSize XXXXL woman who nearly drowned because she was so big loses st to become catwalk modelDominique Montgomery, , survived for years on nothing by greasy fast food - eventually reaching stlb - before a fateful day at the beach changed her le foreverShareCommentsByErin Cardf:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsDominique before she lost weight "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA size XXXXL woman who nearly drowned when she was too heavy to lted from the water has transformed her le to become a catwalk model. Dominique Montgomery, , survived for years on nothing by greasy fast food - eventually reaching stlb. Despite suffering cruel taunts and bullying - even once having a burrito thrown at her by a total stranger at a football game - Dominique never lost sight of her dream to become a model. Now, following a remarkable transformation whereby she shed  stone, Dominique has strutted her stuff on the runway at the USAs celebrated Los Angeles Fashion Week - and will repeat the experience at the New York shows next month. Reliving the terrying  day which changed her le, after she became trapped by a rapidly rising tide, Dominique, of Los Angeles, Calornia, said: “I always wanted to model, but was so focused on being overweight that I had no idea how it would happen. “But now, my confidence has improved so much and I have learned not to be so hard on myself.   “I can’t explain how exciting it feels to be up on that runway. You can’t even see anything as the lights are so bright – all you can hear are cheers.” Embarking on her first diet aged just five, so big her school unorms had to be specially made, Dominique, who has also started her own personal training business, combining mindfulness with fitness and nutrition, has fought a lelong battle with her weight. After trying and failing on a multitude of diets, eventually resigning herself to a letime of obesity, she admitted: “I struggled with an eating disorder that most people don’t talk about – binge eating. “I couldn’t control how much I ate and, eventually, I stopped caring. As I was already so big, I thought nobody would noticeI ate more.”  Enjoying a staple diet of fast food and takeaways, washed down with fizzy pop, Dominique struggled with portion control and regularly ordered meals like fried chicken with double chips and two biscuits – a scone-like buttermilk bake – or a burrito “as big as her head,” with two large tacos on the side. “I would eat at least , calories a day. Sometimes, I would have large shakes for dessert that were about , calories by themselves,” she said. Her self-esteem shrinking with every pound she gained, Dominique eventually took to eating in her car, away from the prying eyes of judgemental strangers.   She added: “My confidence was low. I felt very hopeless and began to irrationally blame every problem in my le on being big.” But everything changed in July , during a day at the beach with friends. She recalled: “I was swimming around, feeling great, when all of a sudden, the tide got high. “Everyone managed to push themselves out of the water onto some rocks, but I was stuck, because I wasn’t physically able to lt myself out. Everyone tried to help, but I was too heavy. “I thought I was going to die and had no idea what to do. I was terried.” Thankfully, she managed to hold on until the water calmed, but she was left severely shaken. She added: “If I couldn’t even help myself out of the water, then what was I doing with my le ” Since then, Dominique, who now weighs just over st and is a UK size eight, has embarked on a healthy regime, ditching the fast food and heading to the gym. But, having been left with folds of excess skin - particularly around her stomach - by her rapid weight loss, while she has toned up slightly by working out, she is also saving for ,surgery to remove it.   Around four months ago, keen to help to others beginning their own weight loss journeys, she even launched her own personal training company. “Lots of people were asking me how to lose weight, so I wanted to devise something that tackles fitness and nutrition as well as mindset. It’s important to look at why people have gotten to that point, and what is stunting their progress,” she said. “I am hoping to eventually make it an online business, so anyone from anywhere in the world can get involved.” Then, in October , after finding herself an agent and trainer, Dominique fulfilled her lelong ambition - becoming a runway star at Los Angeles Fashion Week, modelling for brands Lorenz Couture and Esti Nay, as well as in showcases for The Model Experience and Model Mafia LA. And, shining in the spotlight, all her insecurities about her remaining apron of skin melted away. She added: “With my first show, it did cause a little problem as I’d applied some  tan, which ended up uneven where my skin folded over – but I changed outfit last minute so you couldn’t see it.   “I prefer walking in couture shows, as you can wear lovely long, flowing gowns but either way, when you’re up there, it’s so exciting that you don’t think about much .” In February, Dominique will also be giving a repeat performance at New York Fashion Week, and hopes it will pave the way to one day realising her ultimate dream of starring in the iconic Victoria’s Secret fashion show. “The designs are impeccable, and it is just such a renowned show,” she sighed. Her le – and body – now unrecognisable, Dominique has even written a book called The Gt, in which she shares everything she has learnt about confidence, self-belief and achieving your goals. “All I want to do now is help and motivate people in any way I can,” she said. “I also want to reassure people that it’s okay to go at their own pace and that every dream, everything that starts with a thought, is absolutely possible.”

title: woman called humpty dumpty cow
story: NewsWoman called Humpty Dumpty cow and f***ing tramp after takeaway complaintLauren Barrass, , was stunned by the reaction from two members of staff from Eastend Diner in Blakelaw, Newcastle-upon-TyneShareCommentsBySophie Norris:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsTakeaway customers Lauren Barrass, , who was victim of vile abuse, with fiance Jamie Palmer "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn unhappy customer was branded an overgrown Humpty Dumpty who needed a facelt after she complained about the portion size of her Indian takeaway. Lauren Barrass, , blasted Eastend Diner in Blakelaw, Newcastle-upon-Tyne, in the online review over their allegedly aggressive manner when dealing with her complaint over small portions on Sunday.However she was stunned when Sfu Syed, , who lists himself as the takeaways boss on Facebook , appeared to respond by calling her a f***ing tramp and an ugly b****.After ignoring the abusive post, she says she was contacted directly by his brother Bahar Uddin Syed, , who called her a fat c***t and a Humpty Dumpty lookalike cow. The takeaway claim that Sfu and Bahar are the sons of takeaway co-owner Ashraf Syed and no longer work at the outlet. Co-owner Ashraf apologised for their vile comments over the bad review - however appears to have subsequently removed the apology.   Compliance agent Lauren slammed the half-hearted apology after feeling Sfus messages had been threatening since they goaded her to complain directly to him. Lauren, from Newcastle-upon-Tyne, Tyne and Wear, said: Its so ridiculous. I cant believe how personal and horrible they have been. I felt threatened by the wording and I thought I was more thick-skinned, but with people calling your personal appearance, it does get to you. I left work and I saw the owners son Sfu had written above my review calling me an f***ing tramp and telling me to get in touch. It felt like a threat - I was gobsmacked. I couldnt comprehend it to be honest. Lauren and Jamie ordered a Munchie Box from the takeaway, however when it arrived they claim the portion size was really small.   When they called EastEnd Diner to complain, they were denied a refund and were allegedly spoken to aggressively by a manager. Lauren said: When our order came Jamie took it into the kitchen and I just heard are you joking  The portion sizes were ridiculous so we rang the takeaway to say sorry, this isnt what we were expecting. It is really small - Im wonderingyou could come and pick it back up and give us a refund. The person we initially spoke to said he wasnt going to pay to send a driver to pick it back up because theyd have to pay the driver. The manager came on and reiterated what his colleague had said and started getting quite aggressive on the phone. Jamie, out of sheer disgust, just ended the phone call.  A couple of days later, as Lauren left work she noticed one of the sons, Sfu, had appeared to comment on her post - swearing and mocking her appearance. The post, written publicly on Facebook and later deleted, read: You know what it is [my] dads had his business in Blakelaw for over  years and had never had this problem. All of a sudden some stingy b****h start talking about [my] dads business...Well guess what b***h [my] dads still laughing all the way to the bank every day. He still lives in a million pound house and drives the very best of cars and wears Rolex watches!! Everyone in Blakelaw knows who I am its easy to get my number...you have a f***ing problem ring me U F***ING TRAMPS! He then continued to comment on a photo of the food calling Lauren an ugly b***h and telling her to get a f***in[g] face lt.   Lauren said: I didnt reply to the post because I wasnt going to go to his level. Then I received another message from his brother, Bahar. Me and my partner used to have a business and we couldnt believe it. We wouldnt dream of treating a customer like that. The reason I put the original post up was more about the customer service wed received than it was about the portion size. There were a lot of people saying the way I was treated was a disgrace too. The portion size isnt the point - its past that now. Ive even had people from dferent cities messaging me askingIm okay.  Lauren claims the mens father, Ashraf, had written an apology on the takeaways Facebook page, however this appears to have been deleted. Ashraf appeared to say in the apology: It has been brought to my attention the absolute chaos that has exploded over Facebook and I would like to publicly apologise for the utter disregard and lack of respect my sons have had in dealing with a bad review. I am mortied at the shame they have brought to my business dor and upon my family. Both of them no longer work for the business and I intend to keep it this way! This utter disregard and lack of respect should not be happening in this day and age. Im truly sorry for the hurt, upset and vile comments made by them. Please accept my apology as a means to go on. Lauren said: I did feel for the dad because it was his sons single-handedly ruining his business, but he put an apology up then took it down. The public were saying I hope to god you havent put this half-hearted apology on Facebook without writing to her to apologise directly. Because all the public said message her directly, he took it back down.  Ashraf, the owner of Eastend Diner, said: They havent been working here for six or seven years and they dont live with me either. I wouldnt want anybody to write or say something like that to anybody  - especially something so vile and [in]sensitive. Its just not right. Whatever theyve written or said is out of their own will. I havent spoken to them but they know Im angry about them doing something like that. Ive told their mum to tell them not to come near me. I havent been in contact with them for quite a while. I havent told anybody to write that -you go onto my Facebook I havent written anything. My thinking was the customer has written something, fair enough. Ashrafs sons Sfu and Bahar failed to respond to requests for comment. Eastend Diners manager, Kemran Qureshi, said: They are young lads, they dont know what theyre doing. Why they did it I dont have a clue - its beyond my belief. Im in such a sticky situation. The owner wouldnt accept this behaviour from anybody either - they shouldnt have been writing anything like that. Because its their father that owns the business, they jumped on the bandwagon, I can only assume.

story: NewsThe word Prince George and Princess Charlottes nanny is banned from saying at palaceNorland Nanny Maria Borrallo was hired by Kate Middleton and Prince William to look after Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince LouisShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsMaria Borrallo even has banter with the Queen "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email  Prince George , Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis spend a lot of time with their nanny Maria Borrallo . She was hired by the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge when George was just a few months old and seems to have settled well into royal family le. She lives at Kensington Palace and accompanies the family on Royal Tours and holidays - so its fair to assume she knows them all pretty well.But there is one word Maria is banned from saying whenever shes at work, and its all because of her training. Maria was educated at the famous Norland College in Bath, one of the countrys top child care training centres.   Author Louise Heren spent a year at the college researching a documentary, so knows exactly what the students are taught. Speaking to, she revealed theres one word the women are taught never to say - Kids.Instead, the little royals should always be referred to as children or by their names. Louise said: The word kid is banned. Its a mark of respect for the children as iniduals. Its a strict rule at the school, so its unlikely something Maria has carried with her and now follows in her royal role.  Despite being three of the most famous children in the world, Louise believes George, Charlotte and Louis lead normal lives at home. She said: Given what we have seen of Catherine when she is out in public, shes very hands on. I imagine her relationship with Maria is very close and they collaborate greatly on the care of the children.   Ive spoken to nannies who have worked with other royal families and le is pretty normal. You get up, have breakfast, you go to school and you wear your school unorm whether you like it or not. title: chinese new year facts celebrate
story: NewsChinese New Year facts to celebrate the Year of the PigChinese New Year  welcomes the Year of the Pig, but how much do you actually know about the celebrations ShareCommentsByDaisy Naylor:,  FEB NewsChinese New Year  will celebrate the Year of the Pig "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChinese New Year  is here, which means that the Year of the Dog is over.Families around the world will be celebrating the Year of the Pig, ringing in the New Year with firecrackers, red decorations and food and gts.Here are some Chinese New Year facts that you might not have known:Chinese New Year is also known as the Spring FestivalThe celebrations start on New Years Day and continue for two weeks. They end on the th day of the year with the Lantern Festival, which sees people release lanterns to symbolise letting go of their old selves, and making a fresh start.Its one of the most celebrated festivals in the worldOver a sixth of the worlds population celebrate Chinese New Year, as its observed in China, Hong Kong, Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand, among other countries.Its a public holiday in China, with most employees getting between seven and  days off work. It causes the largest annual human migration in the worldIts traditional for Chinese families to spend Chinese New Year together, and so people go to great s to ensure that they come home for the celebration. Almost three billion journeys are made by plane, train, bus or car in the lead up to Chinese New Year. Its believed that once tickets are released for this period, over , sell every second.On New Years Eve families share a reunion dinner Families in China get together for dinner on the last day of the year, and look back over all theyve accomplished. Its considered the most important meal of the entire year.Many people then watch CCTV New Year Gala on TV. Its a iety show that comprises music, dancing, comedy, opera, magic, acrobatics, drama and martial arts, and runs from pm until : on New Years Day. million people tuned in to watch CCTV New Year Gala last year, making it the most watched TV show in the world.Chinese New Year is the largest annual usage of fireworks on the planetThe likes of Bonfire Night and the Fourth of July cant compete with Chinese New Year, when hundreds of thousands of fireworks are set off to celebrate the new Lunar Year.  You cant shower on New Years DayIts considered bad luck to shower on the first day of the Spring Festival, as its believed that you risk washing away the good luck. Youre not supposed to sweep or throw away any rubbish for five days, and its unlucky to say any negative wordsas well.People also avoid eating meat on New Years Day, and -you can help it - youre not supposed to cry for the entire day.The colour Red is important in Chinese New Year celebrationsRed is a lucky colour in China, and many people wear red and decorate their homes in red to welcome the new year.Its also traditional for people to give each other money in red envelopes during the Chinese New Year celebrations. Traditionally married couples will give them to single people, or the older generations will give them to the younger people in their families.

story: NewsModel Alli MacDonnell in talks to appear on two new TV shows before sudden deathAlli MacDonnell, , from Dublin, Ireland, was in negotiations to front a prank show and a programme about autism when she was found deadShareCommentsByDemelza De-Burca:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video tributes-for-alli-macdonnell-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A model found dead after posting a cryptic final Facebook post was in talks about appearing on two new TV shows, her best friend revealed.Alli MacDonnell, , from Dublin, died suddenly and police have vowed to speak to anyone who had recently had contact with her on social media.The mum-of-four, a regular on TV show Ireland AM, wrote on Facebook shortly before her death: Why is it ok for a man to call z girl a fat ugly C***        Seriously new level of pushing someone to the edge.Police say the -year-olds death is not being treated as suspicious. Speaking to the Irish Mirror , best pal John Compton told how he had spoken to the model hours before he learnt of her death.He said: “We are all beyond devastated. I spoke to Alli yesterday. title: dundee united loan signing charlie seaman wants to return to bournemouth with medal
story: Dundee United loan signing Charlie Seaman has come to Dundee United to develop as a player and get first-team experience.And he also aims to be heading back to parent club Bournemouth this summer with a Scottish Championship medal in his pocket.In capturing the -year-old full-back from one of the surprise success stories of the English Premier League over the past few seasons, Tangerines boss Robbie Neilson stressed the deal was exactly what it said on the tin – a loan.The end of the season will see Seaman head back to the south coast and be expected to challenge for a top-team place with the Cherries.However, while his time in Scotland will be a learning experience, the former West Ham youth wants success as well.“Hopefully, coming here and learning dferent things will help me for when I go back for next season,” he said.“I can learn dferent styles here so I am really happy to be in Scotland with United.“The boys here love to play football and that’s good because it’s that way down at Bournemouth.“Every side of the game, though, on the ball, off the ball I am trying to learn, it’s what I’m here for. Defensively I am trying to be better and I want to be better offensively as well.“I came here to get experience of first-team football. I was waiting for my chance at Bournemouth but I felt I could get it here sooner, get some games for the rest of the season. Hopefully I will be more readyI get the opportunity when I go back, or wherever it may be.“There is a job to do for the team as well and our goal at Dundee United is to win this league. Yes, it would be nice to be finishing the season with a medal for that.”Seaman’s time north of the border hardly got off to the perfect start and, within hours of his arrival, he was tasting defeat as United went down to Ayr.His temporary manager was disappointed with the team performance at Somerset Park but did make a point of saying the new arrival had put in some good work.The young full-back took encouragement from that but has admitted he did not necessarily agree with Robbie’s assessment.“I was happy to make my debut last week, obviously disappointed with the loss, but it was good to get out there and experience something dferent,” he added.“I didn’t think I started the game too well but I thought I grew into it. Still, personally, I don’t think it was one of my better games by any stretch.“It was my first game at the club, my first playing a dferent style of football and my first playing in dferent weather conditions and stuff like that.“It was all a learning curve, something to take from that game into future games.“I came up Thursday night, so I only had a day here before the game but I have high expectations and I like to set high standards.“When I don’t reach them, I’m disappointed.”The aim now is to show up well as he makes his home debut as Morton visit Tannadice and United try to get back to winning ways to keep in touch with leaders Ross County.And Seaman does admit this week has given him more time to do his homework on the opposition, saying: “Before Ayr the gaffer gave me a lot of clips of Ayr to watch so I had a fair idea of what they were going to do.“I was relatively ready for the game in a tactical aspect but I did only come up on Thursday night.“For this game against Morton we have been getting information throughout the week. So I’ve an idea of what to expect and I am looking forward to playing in front of our own fans.”
